TWO-YEAR STABILITY OF FREE AND TOTAL PSA IN
FROZEN SERUM SAMPLES
DAVID WOODRUM AND LISA YORK
ABSTRACT
Objectives. To investigate the stability of free and total prostate-specific antigen (PSA) in serum stored at
Ϫ20°C and Ϫ70°C for 2 years.
Methods. Fresh blood from 29 patients was drawn and allowed to clot at room temperature. Serum was
prepared by centrifugation 1 hour later and tested to determine the free and total PSA levels. Samples were
aliquoted, frozen at Ϫ20°C or Ϫ70°C, and monitored for long-term stability over the course of 2 years.
Results. On average, 91% of the free PSA, 92% of the total PSA, and 89% of the percent free PSA values
were recovered after 2 years of storage at Ϫ20°C; and 96% of the free PSA, 101% of the total PSA, and 95%
of the percent free PSA values were recovered after 2 years of storage at Ϫ70°C. Seventy percent of the
samples stored at Ϫ20°C and 100% of the samples stored at Ϫ70°C showed no statistically significant
decline in free PSA values over the 2-year period. Only one total PSA sample (Ϫ20°C) showed a statistically
significant loss after 2 years of storage.
Conclusions. Our results suggest that samples stored frozen for up to 2 years at Ϫ70°C should give
acceptable percent free PSA results.
